description: At minimum, I exist as a thinking being. This is self-evident and cannot be coherently denied.
Something cannot both be and not be in the same respect at the same time. Contradictory statements cannot both be true.
Our senses, though sometimes mistaken, generally provide reliable information about the external world.
Every effect has a cause. Nothing comes into being without a sufficient reason for its existence.
We observe that things change, move, and are actualized from potency to act. This is evident to our senses.
I am aware of my own thoughts, feelings, and experiences. This immediate awareness cannot be doubted.
My memories of past experiences, while not infallible, provide meaningful continuity of personal identity.
Other humans possess consciousness and inner experiences similar to my own.
Words and symbols can successfully communicate ideas and concepts between minds.
Logical reasoning and rational inquiry can lead to genuine understanding of reality.
Mathematical patterns and relationships correspond to structures in the physical world.
Events occur in temporal sequence, with a meaningful distinction between past, present, and future.
Physical objects exist in spatial relationships with measurable distances and dimensions.
Some actions are genuinely better or worse than others, not merely matters of opinion.
Some things possess genuine aesthetic value that transcends mere personal preference.
Reality has a definite structure that can be progressively understood through inquiry.
While constrained by natural laws, genuine possibilities exist for different outcomes.
Every human being possesses inherent value that cannot be reduced to utility or function.
The universe displays consistent regularities and laws that govern natural phenomena.
Pain and suffering constitute real evils, not merely subjective preferences.
If God exists, it is conceivable that divine truth could be communicated to human beings through various means.
Reliable witnesses can transmit knowledge of past events, including extraordinary ones, through consistent testimony.
The concept of a maximally great being - possessing all perfections - is coherent and meaningful.
Everything that exists but could fail to exist requires a reason for its existence rather than non-existence.
We observe varying degrees of goodness, truth, and nobility among beings, implying a standard of comparison.
Natural things exhibit goal-directed behavior and functions that serve ends beyond mere mechanical causation.
Voluntary trade between parties generally benefits both, creating mutual value and improving human welfare.
Individuals can legitimately acquire exclusive rights to use and transfer material goods through labor and exchange.
Human work possesses inherent worth beyond mere economic value, contributing to personal development and social good.
When people compete to provide goods and services, this generally leads to better quality and lower prices for consumers.
Encounters with the sacred or transcendent can provide genuine insight and spiritual knowledge, not mere subjective feeling.
Truth can be discovered through reason, experience, testimony, and potentially divine revelation across different domains.
Different cultural perspectives and traditions can contribute valuable insights about human nature and the good life.
Humans achieve greater individual and collective good through coordinated effort than through isolated action.
Creative discovery and technological development can genuinely improve human living conditions and expand possibilities.
